“You can see in the way [Dany is] dressing that she’s almost assuming the power but not quite. With all the colors and the details and the essence — it just becomes stronger. The width of the shoulders give her strength, the chain gives her strength. I tried to make the cut of the costumes just slightly more like a uniform and almost less feminine. This is the time when it’s all really going to matter, and so there’s a power play between her and Cersei. It’s like a standoff. And I think they’ve both reached a place where it’s not about femininity, it’s about their strength as women.” - Clapton to Insider

Then again, even the winter coat is a lot more uneven in texture because of it being fashioned after a dragon and it fans out into a trail. Incidentally, both Dany and Cersei have very elaborate spine portions.

“I guess to some extent the ribbed effect created by the construction has the feel of a dragon’s skin.” - Clapton, Vanity Fair

All that said said, Clapton designed the dress to represent Dany’s feelings for Jon, while also playing on her role as a warrior queen.

“But if the intention was to give Daenerys a very Targaryen ensemble, why did Clapton opt for white instead of red and black here? “There were many reasons really,” she says. “It’s cold, so furs are the natural direction available. I felt that there should be a definite shift in her look as she embarks on the mission of aiding Jon’s team trapped north of the Wall. I think it’s the first time that she has really been to the aid of another individual—let’s face it, she’s not going because of the Hound!—and she is putting herself at risk. And for a king at that! Dany is elevating her look to that of warrior queen, with the beautiful silver dragon chain completing the look.” - Clapton to Vanity Fair

Weirdly, Dany’s use of that ribbed texture resembling a dragon actually distances her further from Jon’s look while he’s dressed as a wildling. There is also the fact that silhouette of the white winter coat is inspired by Viserys and the dragon chain, of course, represents her desire to conquer Westeros and her representation of her status. 

“The silhouette,” [Clapton] explains, “purposely echoes that of the Targaryen style that her brother wore in Season 1.” - Michele Clapton to Vanity Fair

“with Dany, she’s wearing a chain across her body as almost a chain of office. A chain of intent. We designed the pin first which is with three dragon heads and then its supposed to move to be the backbone of a dragon, and each piece of chain is supposed to be a separate part of the spine. The chain is there because she can’t wear a crown, because the only crown she wants to wear is the crown of Westeros. But its there to show her status, she’s a ruler… particularly to these new Westeros visitors like Jon Snow… and its there to impress them. It was there to be strong and defiant and motivational. She’s always used jewellery, from the time she wore a slave collar to show her united front with the slaves and then as we advance she gets bigger and braver and it becomes less about Essos and more about her house and being a Targaryen. ” - Michele Clapton to Independent

Strangely, Dany’s dragon spine resembles the slashing on Cersei’s Dragonpit dress. These back pieces look aggressive, while Sansa’s back’s only addition is her belt that is meant to protect her. 

[Edit: une-nuit-pour-se-souvenir made me realise that the “sting in a tail” iconography that I was tying to bees, wasps and broad insectile iconography may be building into a scorpion and it sort of makes sense given that is what the weapon to kill Dany’s is called. So the dragon spine of her white winter coat and Cersei’s “sting in a tail” back may be also visually facing each other.] 

That said, Clapton has said that Dany’s chain of intent and Sansa’s chain necklace also converse with one another.

“Dany and Sansa’s accessories echo each other—and also come from unexpected sources. “We see them facing each other, really. We see the dynamics of this. It’s funny because it comes from different backgrounds. For Sansa, the chain that she wears, the needle on the end represents her Needle, her way of fighting back. It’s a small version of the Needle Arya has. But the chain in a weird way is an influence from Littlefinger. He always used to wear accouterments for his job chained to his coat on a fine chain, and then a mockingbird sigil at his neck. So I was trying to collate all the people who influenced her—whether she likes them or not. There’s a real formality about her chain and the [way] the circle is positioned and looped. That’s very much Littlefinger. With Dany, she is trying to impress that she is the queen in ranking but she can’t wear a crown, so it’s just a huge statement piece of intent—it’s a chain of intent. Visually they play off each other. Whereas Cersei has a look and I think we’ll see in Episode 7 there’s a definite shift.” - Michele Clapton to Harpers Bazaar

So Clapton does want us to compare these characters and their dilemmas down to their jewellery. But she also hints that Cersei’s Dragonpit look suggests a departure from them paralleling visually. Analysing the visually paralleling chains would take a post of its own, so I’ll save that for later. 

But despite their similar silhouettes, Dany’s use of fur on her doesn’t make her look more similar to Sansa. Rather it makes her look more different. The narrow ribbed texture, lack of a belt and visible side flap of Dany’s winter coat highlight their differences.

Interestingly, Sansa’s “fish swimming” dress that doesn’t have a bodice with horizontal lines undercutting its otherwise vertal lines (as in her Eyrie dress) should look more similar. But what undercuts it is the variety of textures (and complementary ones at that) and muted shades that Sansa wears and her tight lacing that masks their similarities. Moreover, with her furs on her shoulders, the dress’ armor like shoulder tabs get masked. 

Also, the choice to not use a cloak is interesting too because once again it distances Dany from not just Sansa’s look but even Jon’s wildling look - even when the colours are geared towards him. It’s fashioned out of Mance’s coat of pelts that Jon’s costume is inspired by on the mission and yet there’s so much amiss about it. 

“Later, Dany’s white fur coat also shows another connection to Northern people. “I took reference from the Wildlings’ attire, particularly the coat that is worn by Jon Snow which was in turn influenced by Mance Rayder,” Clapton said. “I wanted to define Dany’s shape by cutting into and shaping the fur. Also, I was keen to create a warrior look, a thing of beauty.” - Huffpost

As pointed out before, her silhouette is defined by Viserys in this costume and it shows as she sports the side flap that characterises the Targaryen style, that she also wears the Field of Fire 2.0. Moreover, with her platinum blonde hair, she looks too white. So in front of her, he looks like a wildling and she looks too queenly in pristine white and such angular cuts while Jon looks a lot more padded with a number of stitched up pelts of different “dirty” colours like the men on his team. Though what does separate him from them (and Mance) is his cross strap, which again Dany doesn’t wear. It’s to tie Ned’s brown fur around him and is a sign of his status as king. 

Strangely because of Sansa’s cross strap, belt and variety of warm dark colours, her costume complements Jon’s a lot more than Dany’s does - again despite the dresses having similar silhouettes. Even her grey against white, is too light a grey that she looks mostly white. 

Of course, Sansa looks a lot more sophisticated but still within the orbit because she wears colours of black, brown and darker greys because of the number of textures she mixes as part of quilting her dress along with her belt with leather straps criss crossing around her. While her cuts are severe too, it’s important to remember her dress is fashioned after the Night’s Watch armor and her shoulder tabs echo that along with the Stark men’s jerkin sleeves pointing downward (unlike Dany’s that point upward) so there is still more roundness to it and it increases under a cloak with furs. Dany’s costume (added with a dragon) stands out too much on its own because of how finely it’s done and how uncluttered it is with only one silver chain of intent. It might be designed out of a similar material but they still look at odds with each other. 

Dany’s winter coat doesn’t look any more complementary when Jon wears his usual costume which consists of black, browns and greys and no white and a black cloak. I’m bringing up her visual dissonance with Jon because it ties into Northern politics and identity and how Dany fits or doesn’t fit into all of it. 

What’s interesting about this white winter coat is that it doesn’t remain as it was and season 8 promotion has footage featuring Dany in a similar white winter coat but with more red and that has a loaded meaning of Targaryen “fire and blood” considering Clapton withheld it for 6 seasons and only started teasing it in season 7 a bit.

“I think it’s quite interesting that we finally see her embracing her brother’s ambition,” Clapton says. “What does that say? You’re seeing the beginning of something. We’re not at the end yet and I think it’s very important at this moment that we start seeing who she is.” - Michele Clapton to Uproxx on adding in Dany’s red cape and its similarity to Viserys

From the season 8 footage we’ve gotten the red is a lot stronger than season 7 making her white stand out jarringly even more. Red starts replacing the grey in her 7x06 winter coat and as we know grey is House Stark’s colour and the ribbed texture becomes even more pronounced with red linings between those layers of white fur. Her sleeves look like the silhouette of webbed wings like dragon’s but also look like red bleeding into white.

The scale-like beading comes back again in her season 8 costume similar to her 7x01 costume, except in white this time, which is an interesting choice since the receding of it pronounced Cersei’s heavy beading even more, just as the neutralising of colour across the board emphasized the red creeping into Dany’s costumes. 

As @trinuviel has written, Dany costume shows how Dany’s desire to win their approval. The more she tries to fit in with her white fur coat in a sea of grey, blacks, browns and warm blues and with a red silk ascot that isn’t how the Northern undershirt is tied, the more of an outsider she looks. Even when she wears white furs, she looks blatantly different. The white beading on white fur seems a bit much especially considering the silhouette. This again shows how much Dany is trying to merge her own identity and heritage with the Northern culture, and she’s failing because they’re at odds with each other - because of her actions in Westeros, her history and her heritage. 

Additionally from the EW cover, there is a hint of a red sash showing behind her winter coat. People might claim it resembles Sansa’s white cloak from her wedding to Ramsay, but again, the silhouettes and even general material aren’t the same as @trinuviel points out in their post. A red sash on a fur coat looks quite flimsy because again the textures and silhouettes are at odds but as Clapton pointed out, it’s a symbol of status and grandeur.

“The more she connects with her family the more she adopts them into her costume. Plus we can use the chain for a sash of colour, and it has loops where we can loop things through - i didn’t want to use a cloak but it still had to look official and grand.“ - Michele Clapton to Independent

Dany’s sash is purely ceremonial and even the closest thing she wears to a cloak/cape in 7x01 is just an extension of her Mereeen ceremonial cloaks that are a show of status given their cuts on the sides.

In a weird way, it has the same silhouette of Littlefinger’s cloak and her sash is quite similar to his own red sash in season 2. They’re statement pieces that she saw Viserys wearing (x , x).

In some way, I could see how Clapton uses this kind of cloak with sleeve cuts to resemble wings, which are part of both Dany and Littlefinger’s sigils (dragons and the mockingbird). 

Interestingly, neither does Cersei wear a cloak through season 7. At the Dragonpit, she wears a black molded coat with short sleeves. The shoulders look armored in how they’re structured. 

That said does wear a black fur on her shoulders. Incidentally, Sansa wears one outfit like this as well. 

If you look closely despite the superficial parallel, the silhouette of Sansa’s fur is first of all a pelt. It’s also longer, more rounded and shapely around her dress than Cersei’s is. It’s almost as if she has sewn the fur into her dress. Also where Cersei’s is black, Sansa’s is grey peppered with black, like Catelyn’s. Also unlike Cersei, Sansa still wears her belt and chain necklace with her needle. Her armor is still on. It’s always on. 

The cloak and furs are a big part of levelling out this severe structure and making it feel more organic at points. This is one of the reasons why Sansa’s costume still looks complementary beside Jon’s apart from her textures and her colours being black and dark grey complementing his black and brown a lot more than Dany’s costumes. 

Where Sansa wore the palest blue amongst the Starks and a smaller grey fur on her cloak making her stand out and Jon wore a cream fur on his cloak in the back, they now wear grey and brown furs respectively taking after Catelyn and Ned’s fur colours. 

Also silhouette wise, it hides the armor. This comes up in Littlefinger’s trial, where Sansa wears her recurring grey cloak (now lined with fur on its hood) since she escaped King’s Landing with his help. The way she wears it sideways is a bit like how Arya wears her cape in season 7. Under it, she also wears her dress with Eyrie feathers as she passes the judgment of his execution.

[Edit: I’ve thought about how this grey cloak looks a bit misfitted in how it covers Sansa’s neck in Littlefinger’s trial as she wears it to her side. Initially, I thought it was just poor designing but considering the themes I’ve discovered while writing this post, I think it may be yet another symbol of her using it as her armor in a way that the grey cloak that has been used as a motif of her life as a hostage looks “hardened” even when draped to her side because it’s done in such a deliberate manner. It looks very controlled and seems like she has her walls up. Even after we see Sansa and Arya reconciling on the battlements, we don’t see them closing the distance between them as Jon did with Sansa in season 6 finale. Sansa isn’t free yet, because her demons go much further than physical ones.]

Dany and Cersei forgo this throughout, while Sansa only took off her cloak when Jon was still in Winterfell and even then, not always. 

“Clapton noted that Sansa’s (Sophie Turner) costumes contained subtle references to her history, as well. After winning back Winterfell from her abusive husband and his army, Sansa’s stiff, black dress-and-cloak combinations have reflected “an idea of being wrapped, a sense of security, laced in, protected,” the costumer explained. The cut of the costume was very fitted and severe but the fabrics were soft, textured and quilted. I was trying to grasp all that has happened to Sansa, all the hurt and abuse and frustration, and trying to understand how she would express this yet appear strong. She adapts all she has learnt to her look,” Clapton said. Even Littlefinger’s (Aidan Gillen) influence is there, visible “in the precise way that she wears her jewelry pieces,” while Cersei’s (Lena Headey) devotion to family shaped her affinity for Stark family iconography.“These are not decoration,” Clapton said, “they are messages.” - The Huffpost

(Sidenote: Huffpost is incorrect about Sansa’s costumes being black. But they do appear that way because GOT lighting is very dark especially for the Northern sets. In fact stills of Sansa outside and with more lighting show even the Eyrie dress looking grey (x, x, x). It shows most when she is put against Littlefinger who is dressed all in black - albeit with golden silks underneath.)

People jumped all over these references, but there’s context to consider. It’s not about her liking these people or that she wants to be like them, but collecting arsenal slowly and after all that abuse and exploitation that still informs her arc, she’s trying to piece herself back together and armor herself with everything her enemies used against her apart from her family’s influence. She subverts them by adding a needle, which Clapton fashioned after Arya’s, to Littlefinger’s chain, by wearing her Eyrie dress feathers but using it to cover her chest and wearing it against grey rather than black and wearing bold statements of Stark iconography showing what she identifies as despite the marriages she was forced into. It’s like patchwork involved in quilting, like a collage. It’s not all from one place but she’s still trying to place it all together. It comes from a place of defence and fear of harm that will follow more than offence that people assume. A fear of loss of agency and control. And yet, she’s still not at the end of the process. So the narrative does raise the question of “Where is she going? Does she know where she is going? Will she falter?”

“Even Littlefinger has influenced Sansa, in a way, with the decision of how she loops and wears things. She’s taken a lot of knowledge from bad people, and she’s hopefully going to use it to good effect one day. I try to always speak to that—where have they come from and what have they been through.” - Michele Clapton, Elle

She’s a work in progress and she’s not done with putting all the pieces together.  

As I’ve mentioned above the use of quilting is quite interesting interesting against Cersei’s and Dany’s beading. It shifts the mode of textures when she has used it in the past to express herself through recurring motifs her arc. It marks the fact that winter has come with its cold and preservation and sustenance is of utmost importance. It shifts the perception of what is necessary and what is too much as a lot of things are scaled down costume wise. 

Where Cersei’s beading and use of sharp spikes is excessive, colours stand out for Dany a lot more because of red finally coming into her costume after 6 seasons and the way Clapton plays with the presence and absence of red, black, white and grey as she is the character who fluctuates the most in terms of colour in season 7. Still her embroidery and beading, winter fur coat (that replicates dragon textures) and silky sash call a lot more attention than Sansa’s costumes do - whether her fish swimming one or her Eyrie feathers one. She looks modest and conservative in comparison.

This is partly because Sansa is the most stable in terms of her colour, wearing muted dark shades of grey, black and brown, and even textures, which as Clapton says are inspired by her mother’s Northern ones. This is quite noteworthy considering Clapton uses her chain with the circle and needle to represent the dilemma of “Will she falter?” that she parallels against Dany’s “chain of intent”. 

But it makes sense considering she has gone through the journey of first being enamoured by and later betrayed by glamour and then using it to appease another abuser. That backfired and then it became an act of defiance and personal expression. It’s about her sense of self and the loss of it. 

Ironically for being the Stark that looked the most different in pale blue and couldn’t wait to leave home, after escaping Ramsay she sewed Jon and herself fur coats fashioned after Ned and Catelyn and even a deep blue dress influenced by her mother’s colours and she embroidered with a huge direwolf stamped on her chest - like a Stark banner before she took back Winterfell with Jon. Now Sansa stands garbed mostly in greys embracing House Stark’s colours while trying to find herself again. Now when a queen comes visiting Winterfell, she doesn’t look at her with awe and excitement that she did for Cersei but apprehension and judgment for taking away the sovereignty of the North in exchange for aid.   

While clothing and sewing is still a very intimate act for her that connects her to her childhood, she is finally at a point where she understands the necessity of practicality like her mother did. Now as Lady of Winterfell, she is planning sustenance through and beyond the war as well as she prepares for food and making sure people stay warm, which neither Cersei nor Dany seem concerned with. She’s framed as a queen in the making. And tested for it because of the enemies had to face on a very personal level. One has to remember that before season 7, showwise Sansa didn’t have the agency to be in charge of handling matters without an abuser above her. Even in season 6, it was more of battle. So she does falter and still make points about the limitations, but she’s learning in a different way. 

And yet because Sansa basically hides behind an armor so no one can get to her again, people misjudge her. This armor isn’t just political. It’s so deeply personal. But more onto that in the next part. 

(to be continued…)

A/N: Sorry, this was long. There’s just a lot of points that came up and I thought of breaking it down but I’ve been having down with a constant headache for days because of a cold. Keeping it in my drafts only makes me add more stuff to it. So I thought I should get it out. I didn’t cover the comparison of Sansa and Dany’s chains as much as I wanted. I’ll probably bring it up in my next post because it sort of extends into silhouettes in a sense.

trail.content_raw:
“What will you give us?” asked Lucas Codd. “Knitting?”

“Aye, Lucas. I’ll knit us all a kingdom.” - Asha in The Drowned Man, AFFC 

As has been discussed before, all the main female characters in season 7 have symbolic armor represented in their clothing, but the phrases that Clapton calls attention to are the ones that count. And only when they’re seen as a whole and in comparison to the other characters she wants you to compare them with, that one finds more clarity in her venture as she considers costume designing as a form of storytelling.

“I don’t think any costume should be looked at in isolation, rather, through the arc of the character. Each thing will tell a story. It might look like a costume is wrong, but actually it’s supposed to look like that. It’s telling you something about the character at the time.” (Winter is Coming)

In Sansa’s case, Clapton kept bringing up phrases like “binding her against vulnerability”, “encased in her costume”, “tightly laced”, “sewn or laced into her costume”, “no way in”, “no one will get to me again”, “absolute removal of any possible physical touch”, “controlled”, etc. A lot of it was influenced by the inclusion of the belt and criss cross leather straps around her, but that is a fundamental piece to consider while analysing Sansa’s costumes and her character, and every other part is contextualised by it.

In Part 1, I discussed characters and other costumes who Sansa’s season 7 costume’s silhouette was influenced by in order to understand Clapton’s phrases. In Part 2, I discussed the textures on Sansa’s costumes that contrast the severe cuts on her dresses. In this part, I mean to compare her costumes with that of Dany’s and Cersei’s in order to understand them better as they act as characters who visually look towards one another.  

A Comparison of Textures

In season 7, colours were neutralised across the board as winter has come, characters’ costumes started reflecting their deceased ancestors more and Sansa, Dany and Cersei’s costumes had paralleling silhouettes. The costumes were designed around the idea that these women were gearing up for war as all the main characters are finally in Westeros and winter having come. As Clapton mentions, there is kind of “hardening” resulting in their costumes looking like armors. In such a season although there are differences to be spotted in those silhouettes, the textures and their progression through the season reveal and contextualise a lot more on their costumes.  

[[MORE]]

Unlike Dany and Sansa whose costumes change a lot compared to season 6, Cersei’s Tywin-esque black leather coronation dress with shoulder plates carries over to season 7. And one could say that through the season in terms of texture and silhouettes, her costumes through the most changes. All this while her colours of black and silver remain mostly constant with only a touch of gold peaking through some embroidery and beading. In a sense, Cersei has been wearing black in mourning since Joffrey’s death in season 4, which was followed by Tywin’s, Myrcella’s and Tommen’s later. So it’s the hardening that was new, not the colour by itself, and of course the dominance of silver rather than gold. 

Compared to Sansa, Cersei’s costumes have a far more severe look with more elaborate textures, her high collars and sharp and ostentatious accessories. It’s all rather over the top. She wears leather (perforated or bumpy), silk, textured wool, metal and very narrow ribbed patterns. The black leather is inspired by Tywin who wore a similar jerkin like her coronation dress. Behind the perforations is a layer of brocade. Interestingly, even the other ribbed textured black leather dress references Casterly Rock in its elements looking like rocks and being slightly coated with gold and burgundy but this can go unnoticed.

A recurring pattern through these costumes is they all reflect light and “shine” and with the inclusion of armor-like pieces through heavy embroidery and beading or metallic renditions like shoulder plates and chainmail, they attract even more attention. These pieces also tend to include call onto lion iconography. 

 “With Cersei, at this point, she’s attained the throne and there’s a strength in her embroidery. It’s actually quite ornate and over the top and that’s a precursor in a funny way — it’s the last gasp before something else, in my sense.” - Michele Clapton to Insider

Even her crown is a silver broken down tiara as opposed to the ornate gold crowns we’ve seen before. Clapton also designed it such that the central design vaguely resembles a lion.

“I knew so instantly how Cersei should be, looking back at the arc of her story and her relationship with her father. I always try to make the clothes visually tell something – she said very little in that whole scene. I think you could tell it was based on her father’s costume…there were so many elements to it, I loved it. Then to pare down the crown into just simple strokes that to me looked like a lion still, that’s what they’re meant to be, but without that sort of solid heraldic lion that she’s usually worn. I quite liked the idea that it was a move away from that. Which then ties into Dany, the way they look at each other later on.” - Clapton to FIDM Museum

The tie to Dany that Clapton is talking about is essentially her silver “chain of intent” with three dragon heads and that being her symbolic crown before she conquers Westeros and takes the Iron Throne. But more onto that later. Though Cersei’s crown is predominantly silver, there are wisps of gold in it, which matters.

“I chose to make it in silver with just wisps of gold to try to show her isolation, her mental disentangling from her family. There is no reference to [her late husband, Robert] Baratheon; there is no need anymore. She doesn’t have to try and prove a link. The center of the crown is the lion sigil abstracted — its mane represents the Iron Throne, her desire. She has made it her own — she is reborn.“ - Clapton to Vulture

Although we see Cersei dressed in black dresses with extravagant beading and embroidery through the season, we also get moments in private where she wears those same dresses without them. Clapton had this done very intentionally to symbolise her mental state. 

“She uses this beading [as] this sense of power but it’s all quite brittle and it’s all an adornment. It’s not part of the dress,” Clapton explains. “She has a collar and she has these shoulder pieces, but they’re separate from the dress. Everything’s removable and I thought it was really important that her dress, the simple dress underneath is really uncluttered. She’s in mourning. She puts these things on to show strength but there’s a brittleness in that strength” - Clapton

So a lot of this glittering embroidered and beaded armor is meant to resemble glass with its fragility through most of the season. A lot of the beading and metal used look silver in colour, which is interesting because gold is a Lannister colour. It’s absence is part of conveying that fragility at the cost she has had to pay to get here. But you see a touch of gold creeping into her costumes sometimes and that hints the gold is waiting to come back. 

Fragility in this case doesn’t just mean weak and vulnerable (although grief is a great part of it), but also unstable because she has lost almost everyone she has loved. She has no one (apart from Jaime) to protect and there is nothing to stop her from pulling the trigger on the world if she so wishes. 

When you compare Clapton’s idea for Cersei’s armor being brittle because it’s removable, she does the opposite for Sansa. 

“All the characters’ costumes are a consequence of the journey and lifestyle,” Clapton states, particularly referencing a favorite piece of hers — Sansa’s belt. “This is her taking back control of her body. I designed it to wrap around over her side-laced dress to represent the absolute removal of any possible physical touch. Her dresses are also tightly-laced on, incredibly difficult to remove; it’s a message to Littlefinger.” - Michele Clapton, Making Game of Thrones

Her armor isn’t ceremonial or decorative. And little is removable, like her cloak or her Northern collar piece with direwolves. But the rest always stays on. The shoulder pads sewn onto the dress, the tightly laced belt and straps around her and her chain always being on are a big part of representing that armor. 

Unlike Cersei, her dress is her armor and there are no uncluttered layers beneath. It’s not for showing strength. It’s about her gaining strength from it. But like I’ve mentioned before, she’s binding herself so tight it’s slightly oppressive to her own being. 

It’s interesting how where Cersei’s dresses go more outward, Sansa’s go more inward. Cersei also uses a lot more volume in her skirts than Sansa does, showing especially in her coronation dress and her dress with spikes between embroidery. Although the fabric is silk and the texture is smooth, with her beading and structure of her skirts, it looks stiffer and unnerving. 

Even though its a smooth surface, the pleating is quite severe while being flamboyant around the waist and also has an armor like quality in a different way. Yet despite this display of strength, Clapton was once again driven back to the beading catching light and glittering. 

Interviewer: The other costume in the exhibition that has gotten a lot of attention is Cersei’s beaded black gown.

Clapton: For that I really wanted her to be in black because it’s what she’s about at the moment. But I knew she would go down into the cellar and it would be dark. I just wanted those pieces to catch the light, the flames. So it was quite excessive!(FIDM Museum Exhibition)

Thereby, even this dress while it appears strong is still a continuation of that brittleness. The more fragile Cersei feels, the more ornate she gets. 

And of course, there is her Dragonpit costume, which Clapton intended to cue a major shift in her more than either Sansa or Dany.

“For the stand-out dragonpit outfit in Episode 7 however, Clapton used a chain-mail style dress and a black molded coat, with one telling design ‒ a slashed pattern on the back of the queen’s coat. “I knew she was lying,” Clapton explains what inspired the look. “Something about the slashing and the twisting told you a lot about her character, a contradiction of the costume from the front. It’s almost like a sting in the tail, something on edge as you see her walk away: there’s something really disturbing about this woman.”  - Making of Thrones

“Cersei has a look and I think we’ll see in Episode 7 there’s a definite shift.” - Michele Clapton to Harpers Bazaar

So what is this shift we see? So far most of Cersei’s embellishment has been on her shoulders and neck and during the Dragonpit meeting, we see her wearing that slashing pattern representing a “sting in the tail” it on her back. Also we see her in a black molded coat shaped like armor without any adornment while she wears a chainmail like dress underneath. More so, after she walks away and talks to Tyrion in the privacy of her room, she takes off her black coat and only wears her chainmail dress. Generally, it’s been the other way around through the season. 

But after he’s gone and she confesses the truth to Jaime, she is back in one of her black dresses without any adornment. So that play of wearing the chainmail dress while Tyrion was there hinted that she was lying and putting up a front. In the scene where Jaime leaves, she also throws a black fur on, which hints winter in its true form is coming in snow to King’s Landing. With Jaime gone, I imagine her armor is going to shift a bit from an outward show a bit - even if the design would again hint the price she has had to pay to get the throne. 

Given Dany’s dress suits are shorter and worn over pants, they don’t cover that much volume. But it’s not that she doesn’t have details of note and she does show off in her own way. A pattern that continues through the season is how red slowly keeps creeping up in her costumes - even after they recede. 

“With Daenerys, there’s a creeping of red within the scaling embroidery of her coat. It’s like she’s finally beginning to grasp power and she feels closer to the idea of taking the throne, of coming home. Although it’s always been her ambition, whether she actually believed she could isn’t clear, even though she said she could. So I decided that finally now she can start inhabiting and owning her family’s place. I like the emblematic nature of that.” - Clapton to Elle

“This season seemed to be the right time for Daenerys to start to embrace the shape and colours of her house,” Clapton told HuffPost in an email. “She is in touching distance of her desired place … so I liked this flowering, this visual expression of her growing confidence that she could maybe take the throne.” - Clapton to Huffpost

When she arrives at Dragonstone, we see her with beading around her shoulders and chest with dark grey and red beads. In the scene where Jon meets her at Dragonstone, underneath her dark grey dress with red cross stitching, she has her pleated fan-like skirt that has hints of burgundy - even if not yet red in it. Additionally, she takes on a silver “chain of intent” or pin with three dragon heads that comes from Viserys in season 1. It functions as her symbolic crown before she can take back the Iron Throne. 

“With Dany in particular, finally we’re getting the [Targaryen] red. She was a confused woman, she was wandering … trying to seek something. And now she’s finally got her armor, she’s finally got everything, and she can finally echo the style of her brother with the extended shoulders and the red and the symbolism. He always had the big Targaryen [sigil] on his chest and now she’s got the big chain with the dragon’s heads on it.” - Michele Clapton to Insider

Her beading and inclusion of red cross stitching on the hems of her dress takes a backseat after 7x04 (until season 8). However, her silver “chain of intent” stays. This highlights Cersei’s beading and its symbolism of her brittleness as even Sansa moves away from it. Instead, Dany takes on a new dark grey side laced winter coat with cream coloured fur lining in the Field of Fire 2.0. The patterned texture on it is subtly bit scale like. Then she wears white and grey ribbed and quilted version of it for the wighthunt. In season 8, this white coat seems to take on more red lining in its ridges. You can see the progression of these costumes leading into one another.

She also wears her pleated and scale-like red silk sash on her dresses on ceremonial occasions, like bidding Jorah and Jon goodbye and the Dragonpit meeting apart from meeting Jon in the throne room. The contrast between the silky pleated red sash against the rough ridge like textured dress coats also makes the red stand out even more.

All her fabrics after she arrives at Dragonstone have reptilian/ridge like textures that evokes hints of dragon-like leathery textures.

It’s interesting to think about how given Clapton includes quite a bit of fish and bird/dragonfly/butterfly iconography in Sansa’s costumes, both she and Dany somewhat have scale-like and wing-like iconography drawing from different animals. But where Dany is drawing from one animal at this point, Sansa does so from more than one - including wolves. 

When you compare both their textures, Sansa’s is deliberately more rugged around the edges to create the impression of white fur on the hems of cloth strips quilted on her. So while those feathers can look like (fish) scales in an armor, they can also look like fur trimmings. This gets more pronounced when seen beside Dany and Cersei who have more refined textures.   

Also where a lot of Dany’s and Cersei’s fabric and embellishment is symmetrical and Sansa’s is too, hers is a bit more earthy. Take her stitching on the vertical lines of the Eyrie dress. It looks like a clean stitch from afar but up close, they look more like vine branches or thorns or maybe they’re even representative of lacing again. 

When Clapton talked about thinking about Sansa’s frustration, I could see how these lines are were used to express that. Her Eyrie dress is completely deconstructed and is reconstructed considering her disdain for Littlefinger while also using him as an ally they need.  

Her minimised and orderly dress cut is contrasted by these stitching lines or the cloth strips’ roughened hems or the feathers being a bit disarray. It looks handmade, especially up close, rather than custom made like Dany’s and Cersei’s costumes that have clean lines. And it’s not because Sansa can’t stitch better, but rather it reflects her feelings, her trauma, her change and where she is at right now. Because of this, there is still quite an intimate quality about her textures. It’s not just for a show of strength like Cersei’s beading and embroidery. Her stitching and quilting is for herself too. 

Dany’s textures are still less rough and sharp than Cersei’s. Apart from her sashes, her pleated fan-like skirt underneath is of a smoother texture as well. It’s a carry over from time as queen in Meereen when she’s not acting as a warrior queen but sitting the throne. Incidentally, Cersei wears another layer under as well, but again, it’s not as thin or as fine as Dany’s pleated skirt. 

It’s worth noting that Sansa doesn’t have a slit that reveals another skirt underneath - despite that being part of the Northern garb. It’s another part of “binding herself against vulnerability”. Like Sansa, Dany’s armor is a fundamental part of every costume and she isn’t shown taking off her armored layer and wearing a simpler layer by itself. Even so, Dany’s bodice is a lot more armoured from within than Sansa. Dany is a military leader after all.  

“You can see in the way [Dany is] dressing that she’s almost assuming the power but not quite. With all the colors and the details and the essence — it just becomes stronger. The width of the shoulders give her strength, the chain gives her strength. I tried to make the cut of the costumes just slightly more like a uniform and almost less feminine. This is the time when it’s all really going to matter, and so there’s a power play between her and Cersei. It’s like a standoff. And I think they’ve both reached a place where it’s not about femininity, it’s about their strength as women.” - Clapton to Insider

Then again, even the winter coat is a lot more uneven in texture because of it being fashioned after a dragon and it fans out into a trail. Incidentally, both Dany and Cersei have very elaborate spine portions.

“I guess to some extent the ribbed effect created by the construction has the feel of a dragon’s skin.” - Clapton, Vanity Fair

All that said said, Clapton designed the dress to represent Dany’s feelings for Jon, while also playing on her role as a warrior queen.

“But if the intention was to give Daenerys a very Targaryen ensemble, why did Clapton opt for white instead of red and black here? “There were many reasons really,” she says. “It’s cold, so furs are the natural direction available. I felt that there should be a definite shift in her look as she embarks on the mission of aiding Jon’s team trapped north of the Wall. I think it’s the first time that she has really been to the aid of another individual—let’s face it, she’s not going because of the Hound!—and she is putting herself at risk. And for a king at that! Dany is elevating her look to that of warrior queen, with the beautiful silver dragon chain completing the look.” - Clapton to Vanity Fair

Weirdly, Dany’s use of that ribbed texture resembling a dragon actually distances her further from Jon’s look while he’s dressed as a wildling. There is also the fact that silhouette of the white winter coat is inspired by Viserys and the dragon chain, of course, represents her desire to conquer Westeros and her representation of her status. 

“The silhouette,” [Clapton] explains, “purposely echoes that of the Targaryen style that her brother wore in Season 1.” - Michele Clapton to Vanity Fair

“with Dany, she’s wearing a chain across her body as almost a chain of office. A chain of intent. We designed the pin first which is with three dragon heads and then its supposed to move to be the backbone of a dragon, and each piece of chain is supposed to be a separate part of the spine. The chain is there because she can’t wear a crown, because the only crown she wants to wear is the crown of Westeros. But its there to show her status, she’s a ruler… particularly to these new Westeros visitors like Jon Snow… and its there to impress them. It was there to be strong and defiant and motivational. She’s always used jewellery, from the time she wore a slave collar to show her united front with the slaves and then as we advance she gets bigger and braver and it becomes less about Essos and more about her house and being a Targaryen. ” - Michele Clapton to Independent

Strangely, Dany’s dragon spine resembles the slashing on Cersei’s Dragonpit dress. These back pieces look aggressive, while Sansa’s back’s only addition is her belt that is meant to protect her. 

[Edit: une-nuit-pour-se-souvenir made me realise that the “sting in a tail” iconography that I was tying to bees, wasps and broad insectile iconography may be building into a scorpion and it sort of makes sense given that is what the weapon to kill Dany’s is called. So the dragon spine of her white winter coat and Cersei’s “sting in a tail” back may be also visually facing each other.] 

That said, Clapton has said that Dany’s chain of intent and Sansa’s chain necklace also converse with one another.

“Dany and Sansa’s accessories echo each other—and also come from unexpected sources. “We see them facing each other, really. We see the dynamics of this. It’s funny because it comes from different backgrounds. For Sansa, the chain that she wears, the needle on the end represents her Needle, her way of fighting back. It’s a small version of the Needle Arya has. But the chain in a weird way is an influence from Littlefinger. He always used to wear accouterments for his job chained to his coat on a fine chain, and then a mockingbird sigil at his neck. So I was trying to collate all the people who influenced her—whether she likes them or not. There’s a real formality about her chain and the [way] the circle is positioned and looped. That’s very much Littlefinger. With Dany, she is trying to impress that she is the queen in ranking but she can’t wear a crown, so it’s just a huge statement piece of intent—it’s a chain of intent. Visually they play off each other. Whereas Cersei has a look and I think we’ll see in Episode 7 there’s a definite shift.” - Michele Clapton to Harpers Bazaar

So Clapton does want us to compare these characters and their dilemmas down to their jewellery. But she also hints that Cersei’s Dragonpit look suggests a departure from them paralleling visually. Analysing the visually paralleling chains would take a post of its own, so I’ll save that for later. 

But despite their similar silhouettes, Dany’s use of fur on her doesn’t make her look more similar to Sansa. Rather it makes her look more different. The narrow ribbed texture, lack of a belt and visible side flap of Dany’s winter coat highlight their differences.

Interestingly, Sansa’s “fish swimming” dress that doesn’t have a bodice with horizontal lines undercutting its otherwise vertal lines (as in her Eyrie dress) should look more similar. But what undercuts it is the variety of textures (and complementary ones at that) and muted shades that Sansa wears and her tight lacing that masks their similarities. Moreover, with her furs on her shoulders, the dress’ armor like shoulder tabs get masked. 

Also, the choice to not use a cloak is interesting too because once again it distances Dany from not just Sansa’s look but even Jon’s wildling look - even when the colours are geared towards him. It’s fashioned out of Mance’s coat of pelts that Jon’s costume is inspired by on the mission and yet there’s so much amiss about it. 

“Later, Dany’s white fur coat also shows another connection to Northern people. “I took reference from the Wildlings’ attire, particularly the coat that is worn by Jon Snow which was in turn influenced by Mance Rayder,” Clapton said. “I wanted to define Dany’s shape by cutting into and shaping the fur. Also, I was keen to create a warrior look, a thing of beauty.” - Huffpost

As pointed out before, her silhouette is defined by Viserys in this costume and it shows as she sports the side flap that characterises the Targaryen style, that she also wears the Field of Fire 2.0. Moreover, with her platinum blonde hair, she looks too white. So in front of her, he looks like a wildling and she looks too queenly in pristine white and such angular cuts while Jon looks a lot more padded with a number of stitched up pelts of different “dirty” colours like the men on his team. Though what does separate him from them (and Mance) is his cross strap, which again Dany doesn’t wear. It’s to tie Ned’s brown fur around him and is a sign of his status as king. 

Strangely because of Sansa’s cross strap, belt and variety of warm dark colours, her costume complements Jon’s a lot more than Dany’s does - again despite the dresses having similar silhouettes. Even her grey against white, is too light a grey that she looks mostly white. 

Of course, Sansa looks a lot more sophisticated but still within the orbit because she wears colours of black, brown and darker greys because of the number of textures she mixes as part of quilting her dress along with her belt with leather straps criss crossing around her. While her cuts are severe too, it’s important to remember her dress is fashioned after the Night’s Watch armor and her shoulder tabs echo that along with the Stark men’s jerkin sleeves pointing downward (unlike Dany’s that point upward) so there is still more roundness to it and it increases under a cloak with furs. Dany’s costume (added with a dragon) stands out too much on its own because of how finely it’s done and how uncluttered it is with only one silver chain of intent. It might be designed out of a similar material but they still look at odds with each other. 

Dany’s winter coat doesn’t look any more complementary when Jon wears his usual costume which consists of black, browns and greys and no white and a black cloak. I’m bringing up her visual dissonance with Jon because it ties into Northern politics and identity and how Dany fits or doesn’t fit into all of it. 

What’s interesting about this white winter coat is that it doesn’t remain as it was and season 8 promotion has footage featuring Dany in a similar white winter coat but with more red and that has a loaded meaning of Targaryen “fire and blood” considering Clapton withheld it for 6 seasons and only started teasing it in season 7 a bit.

“I think it’s quite interesting that we finally see her embracing her brother’s ambition,” Clapton says. “What does that say? You’re seeing the beginning of something. We’re not at the end yet and I think it’s very important at this moment that we start seeing who she is.” - Michele Clapton to Uproxx on adding in Dany’s red cape and its similarity to Viserys

From the season 8 footage we’ve gotten the red is a lot stronger than season 7 making her white stand out jarringly even more. Red starts replacing the grey in her 7x06 winter coat and as we know grey is House Stark’s colour and the ribbed texture becomes even more pronounced with red linings between those layers of white fur. Her sleeves look like the silhouette of webbed wings like dragon’s but also look like red bleeding into white.

The scale-like beading comes back again in her season 8 costume similar to her 7x01 costume, except in white this time, which is an interesting choice since the receding of it pronounced Cersei’s heavy beading even more, just as the neutralising of colour across the board emphasized the red creeping into Dany’s costumes. 

As @trinuviel has written, Dany costume shows how Dany’s desire to win their approval. The more she tries to fit in with her white fur coat in a sea of grey, blacks, browns and warm blues and with a red silk ascot that isn’t how the Northern undershirt is tied, the more of an outsider she looks. Even when she wears white furs, she looks blatantly different. The white beading on white fur seems a bit much especially considering the silhouette. This again shows how much Dany is trying to merge her own identity and heritage with the Northern culture, and she’s failing because they’re at odds with each other - because of her actions in Westeros, her history and her heritage. 

Additionally from the EW cover, there is a hint of a red sash showing behind her winter coat. People might claim it resembles Sansa’s white cloak from her wedding to Ramsay, but again, the silhouettes and even general material aren’t the same as @trinuviel points out in their post. A red sash on a fur coat looks quite flimsy because again the textures and silhouettes are at odds but as Clapton pointed out, it’s a symbol of status and grandeur.

“The more she connects with her family the more she adopts them into her costume. Plus we can use the chain for a sash of colour, and it has loops where we can loop things through - i didn’t want to use a cloak but it still had to look official and grand.“ - Michele Clapton to Independent

Dany’s sash is purely ceremonial and even the closest thing she wears to a cloak/cape in 7x01 is just an extension of her Mereeen ceremonial cloaks that are a show of status given their cuts on the sides.

In a weird way, it has the same silhouette of Littlefinger’s cloak and her sash is quite similar to his own red sash in season 2. They’re statement pieces that she saw Viserys wearing (x , x).

In some way, I could see how Clapton uses this kind of cloak with sleeve cuts to resemble wings, which are part of both Dany and Littlefinger’s sigils (dragons and the mockingbird). 

Interestingly, neither does Cersei wear a cloak through season 7. At the Dragonpit, she wears a black molded coat with short sleeves. The shoulders look armored in how they’re structured. 

That said does wear a black fur on her shoulders. Incidentally, Sansa wears one outfit like this as well. 

If you look closely despite the superficial parallel, the silhouette of Sansa’s fur is first of all a pelt. It’s also longer, more rounded and shapely around her dress than Cersei’s is. It’s almost as if she has sewn the fur into her dress. Also where Cersei’s is black, Sansa’s is grey peppered with black, like Catelyn’s. Also unlike Cersei, Sansa still wears her belt and chain necklace with her needle. Her armor is still on. It’s always on. 

The cloak and furs are a big part of levelling out this severe structure and making it feel more organic at points. This is one of the reasons why Sansa’s costume still looks complementary beside Jon’s apart from her textures and her colours being black and dark grey complementing his black and brown a lot more than Dany’s costumes. 

Where Sansa wore the palest blue amongst the Starks and a smaller grey fur on her cloak making her stand out and Jon wore a cream fur on his cloak in the back, they now wear grey and brown furs respectively taking after Catelyn and Ned’s fur colours. 

Also silhouette wise, it hides the armor. This comes up in Littlefinger’s trial, where Sansa wears her recurring grey cloak (now lined with fur on its hood) since she escaped King’s Landing with his help. The way she wears it sideways is a bit like how Arya wears her cape in season 7. Under it, she also wears her dress with Eyrie feathers as she passes the judgment of his execution.

[Edit: I’ve thought about how this grey cloak looks a bit misfitted in how it covers Sansa’s neck in Littlefinger’s trial as she wears it to her side. Initially, I thought it was just poor designing but considering the themes I’ve discovered while writing this post, I think it may be yet another symbol of her using it as her armor in a way that the grey cloak that has been used as a motif of her life as a hostage looks “hardened” even when draped to her side because it’s done in such a deliberate manner. It looks very controlled and seems like she has her walls up. Even after we see Sansa and Arya reconciling on the battlements, we don’t see them closing the distance between them as Jon did with Sansa in season 6 finale. Sansa isn’t free yet, because her demons go much further than physical ones.]

Dany and Cersei forgo this throughout, while Sansa only took off her cloak when Jon was still in Winterfell and even then, not always. 

“Clapton noted that Sansa’s (Sophie Turner) costumes contained subtle references to her history, as well. After winning back Winterfell from her abusive husband and his army, Sansa’s stiff, black dress-and-cloak combinations have reflected “an idea of being wrapped, a sense of security, laced in, protected,” the costumer explained. The cut of the costume was very fitted and severe but the fabrics were soft, textured and quilted. I was trying to grasp all that has happened to Sansa, all the hurt and abuse and frustration, and trying to understand how she would express this yet appear strong. She adapts all she has learnt to her look,” Clapton said. Even Littlefinger’s (Aidan Gillen) influence is there, visible “in the precise way that she wears her jewelry pieces,” while Cersei’s (Lena Headey) devotion to family shaped her affinity for Stark family iconography.“These are not decoration,” Clapton said, “they are messages.” - The Huffpost

(Sidenote: Huffpost is incorrect about Sansa’s costumes being black. But they do appear that way because GOT lighting is very dark especially for the Northern sets. In fact stills of Sansa outside and with more lighting show even the Eyrie dress looking grey (x, x, x). It shows most when she is put against Littlefinger who is dressed all in black - albeit with golden silks underneath.)

People jumped all over these references, but there’s context to consider. It’s not about her liking these people or that she wants to be like them, but collecting arsenal slowly and after all that abuse and exploitation that still informs her arc, she’s trying to piece herself back together and armor herself with everything her enemies used against her apart from her family’s influence. She subverts them by adding a needle, which Clapton fashioned after Arya’s, to Littlefinger’s chain, by wearing her Eyrie dress feathers but using it to cover her chest and wearing it against grey rather than black and wearing bold statements of Stark iconography showing what she identifies as despite the marriages she was forced into. It’s like patchwork involved in quilting, like a collage. It’s not all from one place but she’s still trying to place it all together. It comes from a place of defence and fear of harm that will follow more than offence that people assume. A fear of loss of agency and control. And yet, she’s still not at the end of the process. So the narrative does raise the question of “Where is she going? Does she know where she is going? Will she falter?”

“Even Littlefinger has influenced Sansa, in a way, with the decision of how she loops and wears things. She’s taken a lot of knowledge from bad people, and she’s hopefully going to use it to good effect one day. I try to always speak to that—where have they come from and what have they been through.” - Michele Clapton, Elle

She’s a work in progress and she’s not done with putting all the pieces together.  

As I’ve mentioned above the use of quilting is quite interesting interesting against Cersei’s and Dany’s beading. It shifts the mode of textures when she has used it in the past to express herself through recurring motifs her arc. It marks the fact that winter has come with its cold and preservation and sustenance is of utmost importance. It shifts the perception of what is necessary and what is too much as a lot of things are scaled down costume wise. 

Where Cersei’s beading and use of sharp spikes is excessive, colours stand out for Dany a lot more because of red finally coming into her costume after 6 seasons and the way Clapton plays with the presence and absence of red, black, white and grey as she is the character who fluctuates the most in terms of colour in season 7. Still her embroidery and beading, winter fur coat (that replicates dragon textures) and silky sash call a lot more attention than Sansa’s costumes do - whether her fish swimming one or her Eyrie feathers one. She looks modest and conservative in comparison.

This is partly because Sansa is the most stable in terms of her colour, wearing muted dark shades of grey, black and brown, and even textures, which as Clapton says are inspired by her mother’s Northern ones. This is quite noteworthy considering Clapton uses her chain with the circle and needle to represent the dilemma of “Will she falter?” that she parallels against Dany’s “chain of intent”. 

But it makes sense considering she has gone through the journey of first being enamoured by and later betrayed by glamour and then using it to appease another abuser. That backfired and then it became an act of defiance and personal expression. It’s about her sense of self and the loss of it. 

Ironically for being the Stark that looked the most different in pale blue and couldn’t wait to leave home, after escaping Ramsay she sewed Jon and herself fur coats fashioned after Ned and Catelyn and even a deep blue dress influenced by her mother’s colours and she embroidered with a huge direwolf stamped on her chest - like a Stark banner before she took back Winterfell with Jon. Now Sansa stands garbed mostly in greys embracing House Stark’s colours while trying to find herself again. Now when a queen comes visiting Winterfell, she doesn’t look at her with awe and excitement that she did for Cersei but apprehension and judgment for taking away the sovereignty of the North in exchange for aid.   

While clothing and sewing is still a very intimate act for her that connects her to her childhood, she is finally at a point where she understands the necessity of practicality like her mother did. Now as Lady of Winterfell, she is planning sustenance through and beyond the war as well as she prepares for food and making sure people stay warm, which neither Cersei nor Dany seem concerned with. She’s framed as a queen in the making. And tested for it because of the enemies had to face on a very personal level. One has to remember that before season 7, showwise Sansa didn’t have the agency to be in charge of handling matters without an abuser above her. Even in season 6, it was more of battle. So she does falter and still make points about the limitations, but she’s learning in a different way. 

And yet because Sansa basically hides behind an armor so no one can get to her again, people misjudge her. This armor isn’t just political. It’s so deeply personal. But more onto that in the next part. 

(to be continued…)

A/N: Sorry, this was long. There’s just a lot of points that came up and I thought of breaking it down but I’ve been having down with a constant headache for days because of a cold. Keeping it in my drafts only makes me add more stuff to it. So I thought I should get it out. I didn’t cover the comparison of Sansa and Dany’s chains as much as I wanted. I’ll probably bring it up in my next post because it sort of extends into silhouettes in a sense.
trail.content:
“What will you give us?” asked Lucas Codd. “Knitting?”

“Aye, Lucas. I’ll knit us all a kingdom.” - Asha in The Drowned Man, AFFC 

As has been discussed before, all the main female characters in season 7 have symbolic armor represented in their clothing, but the phrases that Clapton calls attention to are the ones that count. And only when they’re seen as a whole and in comparison to the other characters she wants you to compare them with, that one finds more clarity in her venture as she considers costume designing as a form of storytelling.

“I don’t think any costume should be looked at in isolation, rather, through the arc of the character. Each thing will tell a story. It might look like a costume is wrong, but actually it’s supposed to look like that. It’s telling you something about the character at the time.” (Winter is Coming)

In Sansa’s case, Clapton kept bringing up phrases like “binding her against vulnerability”, “encased in her costume”, “tightly laced”, “sewn or laced into her costume”, “no way in”, “no one will get to me again”, “absolute removal of any possible physical touch”, “controlled”, etc. A lot of it was influenced by the inclusion of the belt and criss cross leather straps around her, but that is a fundamental piece to consider while analysing Sansa’s costumes and her character, and every other part is contextualised by it.

In Part 1, I discussed characters and other costumes who Sansa’s season 7 costume’s silhouette was influenced by in order to understand Clapton’s phrases. In Part 2, I discussed the textures on Sansa’s costumes that contrast the severe cuts on her dresses. In this part, I mean to compare her costumes with that of Dany’s and Cersei’s in order to understand them better as they act as characters who visually look towards one another.  

A Comparison of Textures

In season 7, colours were neutralised across the board as winter has come, characters’ costumes started reflecting their deceased ancestors more and Sansa, Dany and Cersei’s costumes had paralleling silhouettes. The costumes were designed around the idea that these women were gearing up for war as all the main characters are finally in Westeros and winter having come. As Clapton mentions, there is kind of “hardening” resulting in their costumes looking like armors. In such a season although there are differences to be spotted in those silhouettes, the textures and their progression through the season reveal and contextualise a lot more on their costumes.  

Unlike Dany and Sansa whose costumes change a lot compared to season 6, Cersei’s Tywin-esque black leather coronation dress with shoulder plates carries over to season 7. And one could say that through the season in terms of texture and silhouettes, her costumes through the most changes. All this while her colours of black and silver remain mostly constant with only a touch of gold peaking through some embroidery and beading. In a sense, Cersei has been wearing black in mourning since Joffrey’s death in season 4, which was followed by Tywin’s, Myrcella’s and Tommen’s later. So it’s the hardening that was new, not the colour by itself, and of course the dominance of silver rather than gold. 

Compared to Sansa, Cersei’s costumes have a far more severe look with more elaborate textures, her high collars and sharp and ostentatious accessories. It’s all rather over the top. She wears leather (perforated or bumpy), silk, textured wool, metal and very narrow ribbed patterns. The black leather is inspired by Tywin who wore a similar jerkin like her coronation dress. Behind the perforations is a layer of brocade. Interestingly, even the other ribbed textured black leather dress references Casterly Rock in its elements looking like rocks and being slightly coated with gold and burgundy but this can go unnoticed.

A recurring pattern through these costumes is they all reflect light and “shine” and with the inclusion of armor-like pieces through heavy embroidery and beading or metallic renditions like shoulder plates and chainmail, they attract even more attention. These pieces also tend to include call onto lion iconography. 

 “With Cersei, at this point, she’s attained the throne and there’s a strength in her embroidery. It’s actually quite ornate and over the top and that’s a precursor in a funny way — it’s the last gasp before something else, in my sense.” - Michele Clapton to Insider

Even her crown is a silver broken down tiara as opposed to the ornate gold crowns we’ve seen before. Clapton also designed it such that the central design vaguely resembles a lion.

“I knew so instantly how Cersei should be, looking back at the arc of her story and her relationship with her father. I always try to make the clothes visually tell something – she said very little in that whole scene. I think you could tell it was based on her father’s costume…there were so many elements to it, I loved it. Then to pare down the crown into just simple strokes that to me looked like a lion still, that’s what they’re meant to be, but without that sort of solid heraldic lion that she’s usually worn. I quite liked the idea that it was a move away from that. Which then ties into Dany, the way they look at each other later on.” - Clapton to FIDM Museum

The tie to Dany that Clapton is talking about is essentially her silver “chain of intent” with three dragon heads and that being her symbolic crown before she conquers Westeros and takes the Iron Throne. But more onto that later. Though Cersei’s crown is predominantly silver, there are wisps of gold in it, which matters.

“I chose to make it in silver with just wisps of gold to try to show her isolation, her mental disentangling from her family. There is no reference to [her late husband, Robert] Baratheon; there is no need anymore. She doesn’t have to try and prove a link. The center of the crown is the lion sigil abstracted — its mane represents the Iron Throne, her desire. She has made it her own — she is reborn.“ - Clapton to Vulture

Although we see Cersei dressed in black dresses with extravagant beading and embroidery through the season, we also get moments in private where she wears those same dresses without them. Clapton had this done very intentionally to symbolise her mental state. 

“She uses this beading [as] this sense of power but it’s all quite brittle and it’s all an adornment. It’s not part of the dress,” Clapton explains. “She has a collar and she has these shoulder pieces, but they’re separate from the dress. Everything’s removable and I thought it was really important that her dress, the simple dress underneath is really uncluttered. She’s in mourning. She puts these things on to show strength but there’s a brittleness in that strength” - Clapton

So a lot of this glittering embroidered and beaded armor is meant to resemble glass with its fragility through most of the season. A lot of the beading and metal used look silver in colour, which is interesting because gold is a Lannister colour. It’s absence is part of conveying that fragility at the cost she has had to pay to get here. But you see a touch of gold creeping into her costumes sometimes and that hints the gold is waiting to come back. 

Fragility in this case doesn’t just mean weak and vulnerable (although grief is a great part of it), but also unstable because she has lost almost everyone she has loved. She has no one (apart from Jaime) to protect and there is nothing to stop her from pulling the trigger on the world if she so wishes. 

When you compare Clapton’s idea for Cersei’s armor being brittle because it’s removable, she does the opposite for Sansa. 

“All the characters’ costumes are a consequence of the journey and lifestyle,” Clapton states, particularly referencing a favorite piece of hers — Sansa’s belt. “This is her taking back control of her body. I designed it to wrap around over her side-laced dress to represent the absolute removal of any possible physical touch. Her dresses are also tightly-laced on, incredibly difficult to remove; it’s a message to Littlefinger.” - Michele Clapton, Making Game of Thrones

Her armor isn’t ceremonial or decorative. And little is removable, like her cloak or her Northern collar piece with direwolves. But the rest always stays on. The shoulder pads sewn onto the dress, the tightly laced belt and straps around her and her chain always being on are a big part of representing that armor. 

Unlike Cersei, her dress is her armor and there are no uncluttered layers beneath. It’s not for showing strength. It’s about her gaining strength from it. But like I’ve mentioned before, she’s binding herself so tight it’s slightly oppressive to her own being. 

It’s interesting how where Cersei’s dresses go more outward, Sansa’s go more inward. Cersei also uses a lot more volume in her skirts than Sansa does, showing especially in her coronation dress and her dress with spikes between embroidery. Although the fabric is silk and the texture is smooth, with her beading and structure of her skirts, it looks stiffer and unnerving. 

Even though its a smooth surface, the pleating is quite severe while being flamboyant around the waist and also has an armor like quality in a different way. Yet despite this display of strength, Clapton was once again driven back to the beading catching light and glittering. 

Interviewer: The other costume in the exhibition that has gotten a lot of attention is Cersei’s beaded black gown.

Clapton: For that I really wanted her to be in black because it’s what she’s about at the moment. But I knew she would go down into the cellar and it would be dark. I just wanted those pieces to catch the light, the flames. So it was quite excessive!(FIDM Museum Exhibition)

Thereby, even this dress while it appears strong is still a continuation of that brittleness. The more fragile Cersei feels, the more ornate she gets. 

And of course, there is her Dragonpit costume, which Clapton intended to cue a major shift in her more than either Sansa or Dany.

“For the stand-out dragonpit outfit in Episode 7 however, Clapton used a chain-mail style dress and a black molded coat, with one telling design ‒ a slashed pattern on the back of the queen’s coat. “I knew she was lying,” Clapton explains what inspired the look. “Something about the slashing and the twisting told you a lot about her character, a contradiction of the costume from the front. It’s almost like a sting in the tail, something on edge as you see her walk away: there’s something really disturbing about this woman.”  - Making of Thrones

“Cersei has a look and I think we’ll see in Episode 7 there’s a definite shift.” - Michele Clapton to Harpers Bazaar

So what is this shift we see? So far most of Cersei’s embellishment has been on her shoulders and neck and during the Dragonpit meeting, we see her wearing that slashing pattern representing a “sting in the tail” it on her back. Also we see her in a black molded coat shaped like armor without any adornment while she wears a chainmail like dress underneath. More so, after she walks away and talks to Tyrion in the privacy of her room, she takes off her black coat and only wears her chainmail dress. Generally, it’s been the other way around through the season. 

But after he’s gone and she confesses the truth to Jaime, she is back in one of her black dresses without any adornment. So that play of wearing the chainmail dress while Tyrion was there hinted that she was lying and putting up a front. In the scene where Jaime leaves, she also throws a black fur on, which hints winter in its true form is coming in snow to King’s Landing. With Jaime gone, I imagine her armor is going to shift a bit from an outward show a bit - even if the design would again hint the price she has had to pay to get the throne. 

Given Dany’s dress suits are shorter and worn over pants, they don’t cover that much volume. But it’s not that she doesn’t have details of note and she does show off in her own way. A pattern that continues through the season is how red slowly keeps creeping up in her costumes - even after they recede. 

“With Daenerys, there’s a creeping of red within the scaling embroidery of her coat. It’s like she’s finally beginning to grasp power and she feels closer to the idea of taking the throne, of coming home. Although it’s always been her ambition, whether she actually believed she could isn’t clear, even though she said she could. So I decided that finally now she can start inhabiting and owning her family’s place. I like the emblematic nature of that.” - Clapton to Elle

“This season seemed to be the right time for Daenerys to start to embrace the shape and colours of her house,” Clapton told HuffPost in an email. “She is in touching distance of her desired place … so I liked this flowering, this visual expression of her growing confidence that she could maybe take the throne.” - Clapton to Huffpost

When she arrives at Dragonstone, we see her with beading around her shoulders and chest with dark grey and red beads. In the scene where Jon meets her at Dragonstone, underneath her dark grey dress with red cross stitching, she has her pleated fan-like skirt that has hints of burgundy - even if not yet red in it. Additionally, she takes on a silver “chain of intent” or pin with three dragon heads that comes from Viserys in season 1. It functions as her symbolic crown before she can take back the Iron Throne. 

“With Dany in particular, finally we’re getting the [Targaryen] red. She was a confused woman, she was wandering … trying to seek something. And now she’s finally got her armor, she’s finally got everything, and she can finally echo the style of her brother with the extended shoulders and the red and the symbolism. He always had the big Targaryen [sigil] on his chest and now she’s got the big chain with the dragon’s heads on it.” - Michele Clapton to Insider

Her beading and inclusion of red cross stitching on the hems of her dress takes a backseat after 7x04 (until season 8). However, her silver “chain of intent” stays. This highlights Cersei’s beading and its symbolism of her brittleness as even Sansa moves away from it. Instead, Dany takes on a new dark grey side laced winter coat with cream coloured fur lining in the Field of Fire 2.0. The patterned texture on it is subtly bit scale like. Then she wears white and grey ribbed and quilted version of it for the wighthunt. In season 8, this white coat seems to take on more red lining in its ridges. You can see the progression of these costumes leading into one another.

She also wears her pleated and scale-like red silk sash on her dresses on ceremonial occasions, like bidding Jorah and Jon goodbye and the Dragonpit meeting apart from meeting Jon in the throne room. The contrast between the silky pleated red sash against the rough ridge like textured dress coats also makes the red stand out even more.

All her fabrics after she arrives at Dragonstone have reptilian/ridge like textures that evokes hints of dragon-like leathery textures.

It’s interesting to think about how given Clapton includes quite a bit of fish and bird/dragonfly/butterfly iconography in Sansa’s costumes, both she and Dany somewhat have scale-like and wing-like iconography drawing from different animals. But where Dany is drawing from one animal at this point, Sansa does so from more than one - including wolves. 

When you compare both their textures, Sansa’s is deliberately more rugged around the edges to create the impression of white fur on the hems of cloth strips quilted on her. So while those feathers can look like (fish) scales in an armor, they can also look like fur trimmings. This gets more pronounced when seen beside Dany and Cersei who have more refined textures.   

Also where a lot of Dany’s and Cersei’s fabric and embellishment is symmetrical and Sansa’s is too, hers is a bit more earthy. Take her stitching on the vertical lines of the Eyrie dress. It looks like a clean stitch from afar but up close, they look more like vine branches or thorns or maybe they’re even representative of lacing again. 

When Clapton talked about thinking about Sansa’s frustration, I could see how these lines are were used to express that. Her Eyrie dress is completely deconstructed and is reconstructed considering her disdain for Littlefinger while also using him as an ally they need.  

Her minimised and orderly dress cut is contrasted by these stitching lines or the cloth strips’ roughened hems or the feathers being a bit disarray. It looks handmade, especially up close, rather than custom made like Dany’s and Cersei’s costumes that have clean lines. And it’s not because Sansa can’t stitch better, but rather it reflects her feelings, her trauma, her change and where she is at right now. Because of this, there is still quite an intimate quality about her textures. It’s not just for a show of strength like Cersei’s beading and embroidery. Her stitching and quilting is for herself too. 

Dany’s textures are still less rough and sharp than Cersei’s. Apart from her sashes, her pleated fan-like skirt underneath is of a smoother texture as well. It’s a carry over from time as queen in Meereen when she’s not acting as a warrior queen but sitting the throne. Incidentally, Cersei wears another layer under as well, but again, it’s not as thin or as fine as Dany’s pleated skirt. 

It’s worth noting that Sansa doesn’t have a slit that reveals another skirt underneath - despite that being part of the Northern garb. It’s another part of “binding herself against vulnerability”. Like Sansa, Dany’s armor is a fundamental part of every costume and she isn’t shown taking off her armored layer and wearing a simpler layer by itself. Even so, Dany’s bodice is a lot more armoured from within than Sansa. Dany is a military leader after all.  

“You can see in the way [Dany is] dressing that she’s almost assuming the power but not quite. With all the colors and the details and the essence — it just becomes stronger. The width of the shoulders give her strength, the chain gives her strength. I tried to make the cut of the costumes just slightly more like a uniform and almost less feminine. This is the time when it’s all really going to matter, and so there’s a power play between her and Cersei. It’s like a standoff.
